header.title: Liber Salomonis: Cephar Raziel (British Library Sloane MS 3826: 2r-57r)
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Solomonic Magic

central_thesis: The Liber Salomonis presents itself as a comprehensive magical manual, divinely revealed by the angel Raziel to Adam, compiled and redacted by King Solomon. It offers a structured system for practitioners to understand and manipulate celestial, elemental, and spiritual forces through precise rituals involving specific materials, timings, and divine/angelic invocations, aiming to achieve practical outcomes such as healing, protection, prosperity, and foresight.

structure_content.summary: This treatise details the principles of astronomy and the influences of stars, emphasizing their necessity for all magical operations. It provides the foundational knowledge for understanding celestial mechanics and their impact on earthly events and magical timing.

Focuses on the virtues and properties of various stones, herbs, and beasts. It describes how these natural substances are imbued with specific powers and how they can be prepared and utilized (e.g., through engraving figures on stones) to achieve magical effects like healing, protection, and influencing others.

Expounds upon the art of suffumigations (incenses), their specific ingredients, and their application. It links different suffumigations to planets, days, and purposes, explaining how their 'good odors' can attract spirits, please the Creator, and facilitate various magical workings.

Outlines the importance of precise timing for magical operations, correlating workings with specific times of the year, days, and nights. It emphasizes planetary hours, lunar phases, and zodiacal signs as critical factors for the success of any magical endeavor.

Details the stringent requirements for ritual purity and abstinence that practitioners must observe. This includes physical cleansing (bathing, clean clothes), dietary restrictions (fasting, avoiding certain foods), and moral purity, all deemed essential for successful and safe spirit interaction.

Lists and describes the names and functions of the heavens, their associated angels, and their operations or workings. It provides the spiritual hierarchy and the entities to be invoked for specific purposes, linking them to celestial influences and elemental powers.

Explores the deeper properties and miracles associated with the 'ark of magicke' and its figures. This treatise likely delves into the esoteric symbolism and practical application of seals, talismans, and divine names for grand magical effects, offering a synthesis of the knowledge presented in earlier sections.

key_concepts.definition: The core text itself, presenting as a divine revelation to Adam by the angel Raziel, subsequently compiled and redacted by Solomon. It serves as a foundational grimoire encompassing various magical disciplines, structured into seven treatises.

A central concept referring to 'the great name complete with all his names whole and even, and with his virtues and his sacraments' (ff 3r). It is also described as '22 elements or figures' (ff 26r) that are the 'root' of divine power, signifying divine names or principles through which all magic operates.

Celestial beings associated with the seven heavens, planets, and specific days/months. Their names (e.g., Capziel, Satquel, Samael, Raphael) are invoked to direct their powers and fulfill magical intentions. They are categorized by hierarchy and function within the cosmos.

Seven classical planets (Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Sol, Venus, Mercury, Luna), each governing specific 'realms,' zodiacal signs, and earthly influences. Understanding their natures, exaltations, and aspects is crucial for timing and directing magical operations and for associating specific materials and intentions.

The four fundamental elements (Fire, Air, Earth, Water) and their associated spirits or 'beasts.' These elements are understood to be foundational to the cosmos, and their properties and interactions are key to understanding the nature of spiritual and material manifestations.

Ritual incense mixtures made from specific aromatic substances (e.g., musk, crocus, lignum aloes, cinnnamon). These are used to create 'good odors' that appease or attract spirits, cleanse spaces, and prepare the atmosphere for magical workings, with specific recipes tailored to planetary influences and desired outcomes.

A strict regimen of physical, mental, and spiritual cleanliness required for the practitioner. This includes ritual bathing, wearing clean clothes, fasting, abstaining from certain foods (e.g., 'dead beast' or 'bloud'), and sexual purity. It is explicitly stated as a prerequisite for gaining divine favor and interacting with spirits effectively and safely.

practical_system.description: The practical system of Liber Salomonis is a form of high ceremonial magic designed to harness celestial, elemental, and spiritual powers for a variety of purposes. It emphasizes strict adherence to divine commands, ritual purity, and precise timing, alongside the careful preparation and use of magically charged materials. The system is built upon a complex cosmology where specific angels govern planets, elements, and earthly substances, all interconnected through the divine power of 'Semiforas'. Success hinges on the practitioner's knowledge, will, and the meticulous execution of prescribed rituals.

rituals: Preparation of Magical Ink and Pen: Involves combining specific organic and mineral substances (galls, white wine, gum, vitriol, mastick, thyme, crocus, muske, amber, balsamus, myrrh, lignum aloes) to create ink, and fashioning a pen from a green reed gathered at sunrise by a ritually clean individual. These tools are used to write holy names and figures.

Engraving of Figures on Stones: Various precious and semi-precious stones (e.g., Rubinus, Topazins, Saphirus) are selected for their inherent virtues. Specific images (e.g., dragon, falcon, lion) are to be engraved upon them under certain astrological conditions to imbue them with particular powers for protection, healing, or influence.

Suffumigations (Thymiamata): Involves creating and burning complex incense mixtures using herbs, resins, and spices (e.g., mirt, costus, mastic, cinnamon, saffron, lignum aloes). These are prepared according to planetary correspondences and burnt at specific times to attract or repel spirits, purify space, or facilitate communication.

Invocation of Divine and Angelic Names: The practitioner must learn and correctly pronounce a vast array of divine names (e.g., Adonay Saday Ehye Asereye) and angelic names (associated with planets, days, and elements, like Capziel for Saturn, Raphael for Sol). These invocations are central to commanding spirits and drawing down celestial influences.

Observance of Ritual Purity: Before and during operations, the magician must maintain rigorous physical cleanliness (bathing, clean attire), adhere to strict dietary restrictions (fasting, avoiding meat, blood, wine), and uphold sexual abstinence. This 'cleanesse' is considered fundamental for spiritual receptivity and protection from malign influences.

Precise Timing and Astrological Observance: All operations must be synchronized with specific celestial conditions, including planetary hours, days of the week, lunar phases (waxing/waning), and zodiacal signs. The 'Clavis' treatise provides the astronomical knowledge necessary to determine auspicious times for different magical intentions.

Operations for Specific Intentions: The text details rituals for diverse purposes, such as gaining love and benevolence (Topazins), increasing riches (Smaragdni), healing illnesses, foresight (Upupa, Scammony), communication with spirits of the dead (using ysope, suffumigation, and a specific invocation 'surgo surgo surgo'), and control over winds, spirits, and devils.

relevant_quotes.text: Liber Salomonis refers to itself as “Cephar Raziel” (ff 2v, 3r, 4r, 12r, 34r), “Sephar Raziel” (fo. 2r), “booke of Raziel” (ff 20r, 46r, 57r), and “booke of Razeelus” (fo. 3v). Solomon is indicated as the recipient and redactor—not the author—of the book in the narrative which introduces the text (ff 2v-3v), though most instructions begin, “Salomon said….” Others begin, “Hermes said…” (ff 9r, 11r, 18v, 24r, 28v, 30r, 31r, 32r, 33v), “Adam said…” (fo. 16r), “Nathaniel said…” (fo. 47r), “Moyses said…” (ff 4r, 4v), and “Raziel said…” (ff 6r, 16v, 22r, 26r, 28v, 31v, 34v, 36r, 37r, 38v). Narrative passages refer to Raziel as the source of the book (e.g., ff 34r and 36r).

The name of this booke expounded in Latine is Angelus magnus Secreti Creatoris That is to say the great Angel of the secret creator And in Hebrew Cephar Raziel it is the booke after Adam written in language of Caldey and afterward translated in Hebrew.

And the I beganne to write all these treatises in a newe volume for that one treatise wthout another serves not to the wholeness of the worke Therfore I made an whole booke to be made of the treatises.
The key to this booke is to knowe and will the places of the vii bodyes above and their natures and their sciences and the domes, and all their vertues after yt it appeared in the earth to me

Knowe thou that who that taketh water in the 4th hower of the night upon the tombe of a dead man wth what spirits he would have speech wthall caste he water upon the tombe wth this herbe ysope And the water be it suffumed wth costo succo musco and say surgo surgo surgo That is to say rise rise rise and come and speak to me, and do this by 3 nights and in the third night he shall come to thee and he shall speake wth thee of what thing thou wilte.

And Salomon said each man that would do any thing by this booke putt he his mynde to the chapter of thymiama tu. That he knowe the kindes or things & justly Can meddle them. And so knowe thou that thou might easily worke by it and wthout travayle thou might fulfill all thing that thou desyrest to see. Now we have fulfilled one Chapiter of fumigiis or fumigacions, and we will say furthermore yet upon wch was or intencion wth the help of God.
Heere endeth the booke of Raziel of the seaven treatises

critical_analysis.relevance: Liber Salomonis is a significant text within the Solomonic magical tradition, showcasing a Christian adaptation of earlier Jewish, Arabic, and Greco-Roman occult knowledge. Its explicit attribution to Raziel, Adam, Solomon, and Hermes places it firmly within the foundational narratives of Western esotericism, legitimizing its contents through ancient authority. The manuscript (British Library Sloane MS 3826) itself is recognized as a sixteenth-century Christian product, reflecting a period of active assimilation and reworking of diverse magical traditions. It provides a detailed snapshot of the practical concerns and cosmological understanding of magicians during this era, demonstrating how complex systems of planetary, elemental, angelic, herbal, and mineral magic were integrated into a coherent, operative framework. The text's emphasis on ritual purity and precise timing resonates deeply with classical grimoire practices and offers valuable insights into the practitioner's mindset and the perceived conditions for magical efficacy.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience for this work includes practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in Solomonic grimoire traditions and angel magic. Its detailed instructions for preparing tools, materials, and the practitioner make it a practical manual for operative magicians. Academically, it appeals to scholars of Western esotericism, historians of magic, religious studies, and medieval/early modern cultural history, offering primary source material for understanding the transmission and evolution of magical thought.
